key_title: Key to the species of Lepidium

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Brassicaceae

source.author: Entwisle, T.J.
source.title: Brassicaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Entwisle, T.J. (1996). Brassicaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Fruit indehiscent, usually wider than long, cordate or distinctly notched at base (L. didymum is also notched at apex)
Fruit dehiscent, not wider than long, attenuate or obtuse at base
Stem leaves entire or shallowly toothed; fruit 3–5 mm long; petals more than 2 mm long
At least some stem leaves pinnately lobed (sometimes entire immediately below the inflorescence); fruit 1–3 mm long; petals less than 2 mm long
Fruit notched at apex; valve surface with small pits or warts
Fruit acute at apex; valve surface with prominent ridges and peaks
Mature stems smooth, scabrous or papillose, or rarely with a few scattered hairs
Mature stems (above basal part which may be glabrescent) at least moderately covered with acute or bladder-like hairs
Fruits 6–9 mm long; sepals 2–6 mm long; north-west Victoria
Fruits 6 mm long or less; if fruits c. 6 mm long, then sepals 1.5 mm or less
Leaves smooth; sepals more than 3 mm long; fruit with short (c. 1mm) stalk beyond end of pedicel (usually on limestone-derived soils)
Leaves papillose; sepals less than 3 mm long; fruit borne directly on pedicel
Inflorescence a corymb (not elongating)
Inflorescence an elongating raceme
Leaves without hairs, smooth or with scattered dome-shaped tubercles
Leaves with hairs or conical papillae (indumentum sometimes sparse or on margins only)
Fruit 2–3.5 mm long, 1.5–2.5 mm wide; stamens 2
Fruit 4.5–6 mm long, 3–4.5 mm wide; stamens 4–6
Pedicels shorter than or equal to fruit, with minutely hairy upper surface
Pedicels longer than fruit, without hairs (or rarely with a few scattered hairs on some pedicels)
Stem leaves spathulate, 2–6 mm wide; pedicels 4–6 mm long; coastal
Stem leaves narrowly linear, 1–2 mm wide; pedicels 2–3 mm long; north-west Victoria
Petals 1.5–2 times longer sepals, expanded; stamens 6
Petals as long or shorter than sepals and narrow, or absent; stamens 2 or 4
Fruit more than 4.5 mm long, distinctly winged and with a deep apical notch, style not extending beyond notch; probably not in Victoria, see note after genus description
Fruit less than 4.5 mm long, not winged, not or hardly notched at apex, if notched then style extending beyond notch; probably not in Victoria, see note after genus description
Petals absent; fruit obcordate with broad, rounded apical wings leaving a distinct, open apical notch
Petals present or absent; fruit ovate to elliptic with a narrow apical notch
Pedicels without hairs (or rarely with a few scattered hairs on some pedicels), longer than fruit
Pedicels minutely hairy on upper surface, longer or shorter than fruit
Basal leaves toothed but (except very rarely) not pinnately lobed; marginal hairs of leaves needle-like; pedicels shorter than or equal to fruit; stem without papillae
Basal leaves pinnately lobed, lobes narrowly linear; marginal hairs of leaves conical to claw-like; pedicels about equal to or longer than fruit; stem with or without papillae
Fruit papillose; annual or biennial
Fruit with or without hairs, but not papillose; annual to perennial
Stem with short, conical protuberances (more like a papilla than a hair); stamens 6; shrub
Stem with narrow hairs; stamens 2 or 4; herb or shrub
All leaves lobed or dissected to some extent
At least upper stem leaves not lobed or divided (but may be toothed)
Erect shrub more than 10 cm high; nectaries inconspicuous at base of petals, shield-shaped
Decumbent shrub less than 20 cm high; nectaries linear, equal in length to petals
Stems with white, turgid, bladder-like hairs
Stems-hairs not as above
Petals longer than sepals; fruit circular to broadly ovate; probably not in Victoria, see note after genus description
Petals shorter than sepals; fruit ovate, elliptic or obovate
Spines on small branches and terminating inflorescence
Plant without spines
Stem leaves spathulate to narrowly wedge-shaped, marginal hairs arising from warty projection; stem usually scabrous, with mostly defiexed hairs
Stem leaves linear-lanceolate, marginal hairs not arising from warty projection; stem covered with short, fine spreading hairs
